Tides of blood is on a 4.5 second cooldown.

It can stack up to four times.

If you just hit the ability every time it's up in a minion wave, you will get 4 stacks in 18 seconds. That sounds like a long time, but considering that the stacks last for ten seconds, it is moderately easy to stay on four stacks by constantly standing in a minion wave or harassing your opponent. This also isn't factoring in cooldown reduction, either. At 40% CDR, it is on a 2.7 second cooldown, which means you can hit max stacks at 10.8 seconds of spamming the ability. Each stack increases all forms of Vladimir's spell vamp, self-healing and health regeneration, which also stacks with itself multiplicatively. Spell vamp is only 33% effective in AoE, which Tides of Blood is counted as. However, it is 100% effective on single-target spells, such as Vlad's Q. Each stack of Tides of Blood increases all these effects by 4% per stack at level 1 to 8% per stack at level 5. However, as I said, these stacks are multiplicative, which means you don't get 8%/16%/24%/32% from your stacks at level 5, you get 8%/16.64%/25.9712%/36.048896% increased healing effects from your stacks at level 5. If you combine this with the item Spirit Visage and the mastery Second Wind, if you are below 25% health, you will get 42.56%/53.9648%/66.281984%/79.58454272% increased healing effects. Your spell vamp, health regen, and self-healing for all of your abilities is increased by 80% with just Spirit Visage and a mastery and four level 5 E stacks.

So, what does that mean? Well, if you drink a health potion, you would probably get about 270 health instead of the usual 150 health. Vladimir's base health regen is 17.2 at level 18. With all of what I just mentioned, it will be 30.96. Your spell vamp would also be pretty extreme. If you JUST had a hextech revolver for spell vamp, it would go from 12% normally to 21.6%. Spell vamp applies during the damage of an ability. Let's just see what Vlad's Q does with only 2 items, a mastery, and 4 stacks on a level 5 E while below 25% health:

Q on-hit damage: 90/125/160/195/230 (+60% AP)
Spell Vamp applies 100% to single target abilities
21.6% of 230 is 49.68, or about 50 health. This is just from base damage alone.
Let's assume you have a low 120 AP. 60% of 120 is 72
72 + 230 is 307
21.6% of 307 is 66.312 health healed.
This may not sound like much, but we are using max rank Q and not counting damage/heal from E, with only 1 spell vamp item (3 items technically, assuming you're not using Deathcap as your 120 AP item and that we ignore extra damage from Luden's)
And this ability at max rank is on a 4 second cooldown without CDR.
Single target and undodgeable. With only ONE spell vamp item, ONE AP item, and a Spirit Visage
And I'm not even factoring in the bonus health given from the ability itself, which is not affected by spell vamp but still scales off AP.

That's all I feel like typing for now. You can probably just extrapolate and imagine what a full-build Vladimir would be like with all of this.

Vladimir's entire tactic is to just out-sustain you to death. Purely and simply, that is his goal. There are several factors, combined with the champion itself which can make this unhealthy

**1. Vladimir has no mana.** This is one of the biggest issues I have with him (or mostly any manaless champ, really) in that he is unconstrained by anything except cooldowns to continue attacking you. And, let's face it, those health costs aren't going to affect you after you get your core item. On other champions, like Gnar, this is mostly an annoyance. But on Vladimir, when you can actually get substantial amounts of health from nothing but spam, then it's a huge problem.

**2. Vladimir can be untargettable.** This is less of an issue I have in the laning phase and more of an issue I have in any general circumstance. Being untargettable is a very powerful form of utility, and while his offers no gap closers, it is the longest untargettable ability in the game. I understand that the health cost for this ability is actually pretty substantial,  but between 20% of your current health or getting hit by tons of damage, I'd easily take the former. I'll give that Vladimir seems to pay more for having this ability in his kit than others (e.g. Fizz, Ekko). But yeah, it also heals him. Because, you know, he doesn't already have enough sustain.

**3. Vladimir is entirely point-and-click.** This is something that is obviously controversial territory. On one hand, point-and-click abilities tend to be purposefully made to be substantially weaker than they're skillshot counterparts in exchange for their much higher rate of hits. On the other hand, this can lead to much more effective harassing, damaging, and is much more difficult for enemies to react to in-game. It's not necessarily bad, he pays for it by having low range, but it's a health problem nonetheless. I'm also not saying to make everything he has skillshots, either, because I hate it when that's the only solution the balance team can come up with. It's not a hugely bad problem, but a problem nonetheless.

**4. Vladimir is rewarded with tankiness for building damage, or vice versa.** The absolute number-one complaint from every player who complains about Riven, no matter what elo, is that she is rewarded with a very effective shield for building nothing but damage. To be fair, Singed also has an ability like this, except like Vladimir's, it's a passive and remains with him throughout the game. I personally think the general idea of getting the best of both tankiness _and_ damage is something you have to tread very lightly in. In the case of Vladimir, it's only health, but with the interesting quirk in that it also works the other way around, where he gains AP for however much health he builds. Given, the exchange rates aren't the highest (AP = 2.5% bonus health; Health = 140% AP) and they seem to favor more towards building AP than health. However, this is quite an interesting issue, in that Vladimir, if he gets behind, can indeed build tank and still do damage assuming he gets enough health. I'm also not counting health and AP modifiers making issues with his passive (Items like Rabadon's, or Masteries like Juggernaut) and increasing the exchange rates by more than they should.

I understand Vladimir's strengths and weaknesses, and I honestly believe that the strengths he is given are just way too good for someone built entirely around sustain. At the moment, I don't have any solutions that could put him in a good spot, but I might eventually have an idea to get him into a place where he's not so binary and tough to deal with.

I think you're misunderstanding the entire topic of the post, really. Toxic =/= strong, it just means poorly designed, and for Vladimir's goal of out-sustaining his enemy and what he is given to perform that task, it is quite toxic. Toxic kits tend to be complained about more often on stronger champions, simply because they are strong and toxic at the same time.

Take, for example, pre-rework Sion. He wasn't a strong champion, but he was often regarded as being one of the most toxic champions in the League. All a Sion then would do is leave E on the entire game, charge and detonate shield for some waveclear to assist in getting your bonus health, and Q if someone feels threatening. He had absolutely no power in teamfights unless he purposefully charged his shield beforehand and then tried to stand in the middle of the enemy team. After that, he would stun the carry and then become a meatshield. Alternatively, he would be one of the most annoying split pushers in the game, with a lock-on instant stun every 4-ish seconds. You pretty much had to have 2 or 3 people to deal with Sion alone, but he was almost entirely useless in teamfights and had no presence there. It was unfun to fight him, it was unfun to play as him, it was just generally boring and extremely binary.

This is a similar issue with Vladimir, although he is also a pretty strong champion. You claim that his power spike will take a while to achieve, but really, even if you skip the long-drawn-out methods I said a couple posts earlier, a hextech revolver will surely get him at least manageable. What you say is to counterpick him by intentionally bullying him out of lane with some type of early game bully. This is just way easier said than done, due to his harass and sustain being pretty good even at these early levels, despite their significantly longer cooldowns. Plus, counterpicking does not exist in blind pick or teambuilder, so that option of fighting him is practically exhausted. Both Nasus and Vladimir share some amount of sustain, otherwise they would simply be bullied out of lane, but this isn't always the case.

If you were to take a non-ranged fighter into a Nasus, with the intent of harassing the ever-loving hell out of him, his farming may be hindered, but it's not going to stop him from farming under tower. Plus, Nasus has one of the greatest peels in a single ability that has ever been created, which is especially useful on those low-mobility champs. It's not impossible to bully out a Vladimir, but he's going to get a revolver and then it will be so much harder for you to affect him. It's not fun to play a game where you have to babysit this one guy and make sure he doesn't get as much farm, so that at least when he gets his revolver, you'd have a chance to get a {{item:3211}} or something.

My other post explaining the power behind his abilities was merely just a post showing how strong he was. If you could heal more than half a health potion in the damaging portion of a single, 4 second cooldown no-cost ability with only 3 items, not counting any other runes, masteries, or health from practically every other source, then I'd probably say something was wrong.

Keep saying to just bully him out of lane and that he is extremely weak. This is how all carry-oriented champions start out. They just have to play a game of survival for the first 10 minutes and then once they get some items they simply outscale their opponent. There is a reason that Nasus and Vladimir are NOT underplayed (at least just from personal experience in lower elo, although they are far from as uncommon as you make them sound) is because of their carry-oriented kits. A game is very unlikely to end before 20 minutes, but games can go on upwards to an hour, with some extreme cases lasting significantly longer. Hypercarry/hyperscaling champs remain useful throughout this entire time. Yeah, you could pick Darius and go against Vlad, but unless he absolutely stomps Vlad, Darius is going to fall off due to his poor late-game scaling, and Vlad will just slowly increase in power. This is normal for people like Nasus, where the only response is just to stay in lane and hammer the hell out of them until they go farm a different lane, or they buy a core item that increases their damage or survivability even more.

Vladimir is not as strong as other people, but he is so much more of a pain to go against that I'd just rather not. With the AP item changes and poor MR itemization, Vlad will remain to be pretty strong, even if put a good ways behind, simply because all it takes is a few items to get back in completely. He scales, but he scales too hard, and when his goal is to out-sustain, it will cause significant issues.
